sen.j: 馬廻（うままわり）は、戦国時代 (日本)に生まれた武家の職制のひとつである。
sen.e: The Umamawari was established in the Sengoku Period (Period of Warring States) (Japan) and was a job based on the government service system for samurai families.
The Umamawari was established in the Sengoku Period (Period of Warring States) (Japan) and was a job based on the government service system for samurai families.
The Umamawari was established in the Sengoku Period (Period of Warring States) (Japan) and was a job based on the government service system for samurai families.

sen.j: 騎馬の武士で、大将の馬の周囲（廻り）に付き添って護衛に当たったり、伝令や決戦兵力として用いられた。
sen.e: The Umamawari was a samurai warrior on horseback and worked to guard and stay around ("mawari") the boss's horse or served for a messenger or a military force.
The Umamawari was a samurai warrior on horseback and worked to guard and stay around ("mawari") the boss's horse or served as a messenger or in the military force.
Horse guards were mounted samurai retainers who accompanied commanders' horses as their bodyguards and served as messengers or soldiers in wars.
sen.cmt: FBに基づき修正しました。

sen.j: 平時にも大名の護衛となり、事務の取次ぎなど大名の側近として吏僚的な職務を果たすこともあった。
sen.e: Even in ordinary times, the Umamawari was guarding a daimyo (feudal lord) and sometimes performed administrative jobs or functions such as contact person as the daimyo's close confidant.
Even in ordinary times, the Umamawari guarded the daimyo (feudal lord) and sometimes performed administrative jobs or functions such as acting as a contact person and as the daimyo's close confidant.
They also served as bodyguards for feudal lords (daimyo in Japanese) and performed administrative duties as their aides or deputies.
sen.cmt: FBに基づき修正しました。

sen.j: 大名家によって様々な呼び名があり、後北条氏の馬廻衆が有名である。
sen.e: They were differently called by daimyo families, and the Umamawari-shu which was serving the Gohojo clan is well known.
They were called differently by different daimyo families, and the Umamawari-shu who served the Gohojo clan, is well known.
Horse guards were called differently by different daimyo families, and among them, those who served the Gohojo clan are particularly well known.
sen.cmt: FBに基づき修正しました。

sen.j: 織田信長の馬廻衆は、小姓と並んで土豪の次男・三男などから編成され、信長の側近として活躍した。
sen.e: The Umamawarishu of Nobunaga ODA was formed with Kosho (pages) and also the second and third sons of local ruling families and worked very hard as Nobunaga's close confidants.
The Umamawarishu of Nobunaga ODA was formed from Kosho (pages) and also the second and third sons of the local ruling families and worked very hard as Nobunaga's close confidants.
Nobunaga ODA's horse guards, just like pages who served him, were chosen from among the second and third sons of local ruling families and played important roles as Nobunaga's aides.
sen.cmt: FBに基づき修正しました。

sen.j: 信長の馬廻・小姓の精鋭は赤・黒二色の母衣衆に抜擢され、そこから部隊の指揮官に昇進した例も多い。
sen.e: Elite Umamawari and Kosho people of Nobunaga were selected for horo shu (elite bodyguard unit) colored black and red, and there were many cases that part of the horo shu was promoted to the commander of a troop.

Elite Umamawari and Kosho individuals around Nobunaga were selected as members of horo shu (elite bodyguard unit) colored black and red, and there were many cases were some of the horo shu were promoted to be troop commanders.

Elites among Nobunaga's horse guards and pages were chosen as his personal bodyguards known as "red guards" and "black guards" and many of these bodyguards were promoted to the position of troop commander.
sen.cmt: FBに基づき修正しました。

sen.j: 江戸時代においても、諸藩の職制として存続し、大名の日常の警護を務めた。
sen.e: Still in the Edo Period, the Umamawarishu survived through as part of the government service system, and was responsible for the daily guard of a daimyo.
Even in the Edo Period, the Umamawarishu survived as members of the government service system, and were responsible for day-to-day guarding of a daimyo.
Horse guards continued to exist during the Edo period as part of the staff organization of various domains and served feudal lords as bodyguards in their daily lives.
sen.cmt: FBに基づき修正しました。

sen.j: 江戸幕府の職制では、両番と呼ばれる書院番・小姓組が諸藩における馬廻にあたる。
sen.e: Under the government service system of the Edo Bakufu, Shoinban (castle guards) and Koshogumi (page corps) called Ryoban are equivalent to the Umamawari in many domains.
Under the government service system of the Edo Bakufu, Shoinban (castle guards) and Koshogumi (page corps) called Ryoban were equivalent to the Umamawari in many domains.
Under the government service system of the Edo Bakufu, Shoinban (castle guards) and Koshogumi (page corps) called Ryoban were equivalent to the Umamawari in many domains.

sen.j: 旗本の子弟はまず両番に任ぜられ、将軍の側近として認められて、幕府官僚として出世してゆくのが通例であった。
sen.e: After the children of Hatamoto retainer (direct retainer of the shogun) were first assigned for the Ryoban, they became recognized as a close confidant for the shogun and followed a path to move up the ladder as a bakufu bureaucrat, that was a common way for advancement at that time.

After the children of the Hatamoto retainer (direct retainer of the shogun) were first assigned to the Ryoban, they became recognized as close confidants for the shogun, and followed a path of moving up the ladder as bakufu bureaucrats, and this was a common advancement route at that time.

A child of the Tokugawa shogunate's direct vassal (called "hatamoto" in Japanese) was normally appointed as either a castle guard or a page and served as an aide of the shogun before starting out on his career as a shogunate government official.
sen.cmt: FBに基づき修正しました。

sen.j: 馬廻は、諸藩においては職制のほか、家格の呼称としても使用されることが多かった。
sen.e: In many domains, the term "umamawari" was often used to describe a family status or rank in addition to the government service system.
In many domains, the term "umamawari" was often used to describe family status or rank in addition to the government service system.
In various feudal domains, the word "umamawari" (horse guard) was used not only as an occupational title but also to describe family status or ranks.
sen.cmt: FBに基づき修正しました。

sen.j: 藩によって馬上資格を認める藩と認めない藩があって、どちらが一般的であるかは断言できない。
sen.e: Some domains admitted Bajoshikaku (a qualification of mounted warrior) and other domain did not admit it for the Umamawari personnel, so it is hard to tell which was common.
sen.cmt: ”馬上資格”とは、騎馬武者の資格のことでしょうか？検索してもはっきりわからなかったので、一応そのように英訳しました。
sen.e: Some domains allowed Bajoshikaku (qualification as a mounted warrior) for Umamawari personnel, but some did not, so it is hard to determine which was most common.
Some domains allowed umamawari personnel to ride horses to perform their duties while others did not, and it is difficult to tell which of these practices was more common.
sen.cmt: FBに基づき修正しました。

sen.j: 馬廻に馬上資格を認めない藩にあっては、給人または給人席以上を馬上資格としたり、家老から直接統率を受ける家格以上の家臣を馬上資格とするなど様々な基準があった。
sen.e: Domains where the Bajoshikaku was not admitted established various standards in which personnel of Kyunin (upper class retainers) and Kyuninseki and the higher ranks were given the Bajoshikaku, or samurai warriors higher than the family status or ranks under a direct control by Karo (chief retainer) were given the Bajoshikaku.

Domains where the Bajoshikaku was not admitted established various standards by which personnel of Kyunin (upper class retainers) and Kyuninseki and higher ranks were given the Bajoshikaku, and samurai warriors with high family status or ranks under the direct control of Karo (chief retainer), were also given the Bajoshikaku.

Domains that did not allow umamawari to ride horses adopted different standards regarding the qualification as mounted retainers - some domains regarded those who held ranks higher than "kyunin" (direct vassals of lords) as being qualified as mounted retainers, while others regarded only retainers who belonged to families directly supervised by the chief retainer (known as "karo") as being qualified.
sen.cmt: FBに基づき修正しました。

sen.j: 職制並びに家格上、給人と馬廻が併存する藩とどちらかだけが存在する藩もある。
sen.e: There were domains where both Kyunin and Umamawari existed and either of the two existed based on the government service system and family status or ranks.
There were domains where both Kyunin and Umamawari existed or either of the two existed, based on the government service system and family status or rank.
In some domains, the words "kyunin" and "umamawari" were both used to express occupational titles or family ranks, while in others only one of these words was used.
sen.cmt: FBに基づき修正しました。

sen.j: 家格に給人と馬廻が併存する藩にあっては給人のほうが格上である。
sen.e: In a domain where both Kyunin and Umamawari existed for family status or ranks, the Kyunin was higher than the Umamawari.
In a domain where both Kyunin and Umamawari existed due to family status or rank, the Kyunin were superior to the Umamawari.
In a domain where both Kyunin and Umamawari existed due to family status or rank, the Kyunin were superior to the Umamawari.

sen.j: 馬上資格がない馬廻は、江戸幕府の小十人とほぼ同義であって、藩主への謁見資格があるが、馬乗りにはなれない中堅家臣である。
sen.e: The Umamawari without the Bajoshikaku was defined almost the same as Kojunin (escort guard) in the Edo Period and was a middle-class samurai who was qualified to have an audience with a lord, but unqualified to ride a horse.

The Umamawari without the Bajoshikaku were defined as almost the same as Kojunin (escort guard) in the Edo Period, and were middle-class samurai who were qualified to have audience with a lord, but were not qualified to ride a horse.

Umamawari personnel who were not allowed to ride horses were equivalent to escorts (called "kojunin") of the Tokugawa shogunate - they were middle-ranking retainers that were allowed to have an audience with their lords but not allowed to ride horses.
sen.cmt: FBに基づき修正しました。

sen.j: 馬廻に馬上資格がある藩では、馬廻の家格は、広義の上級家臣の下位を意味すると言える。
sen.e: In a domain where the Bajoshikaku was available for the Umamawari, the family status or rank of the Umamawari seems to be equal to the lower rank of broadly high-class samurai families.
In a domain where the Bajoshikaku were available for the Umamawari, the family status or rank of the Umamawari seems to have been equal to the lower rank of the broadly high-class samurai families.
In domains where umamawari were allowed to ride horses, families with the umamawari status were mostly lower-ranking families among upper-class retainers in the broad sense.
sen.cmt: FBに基づき修正しました。

sen.j: 元禄赤穂事件で有名な赤穂藩浅野氏の馬廻役がその典型的な例である。
sen.e: Referring to the domain of Ako which is famous for the Genroku Ako Incident, the role of Umamawari played by the Asano clan is a typical case for that.
Referring to the domain of Ako, which is famous for the Genroku Ako Incident, the role of the Umamawari played by the Asano clan is a typical case.
The umamawari of the Asano clan of the Ako Domain, well known for the Ako Incident during the Genroku era, were typical examples of this type of umamawari.
sen.cmt: FBに基づき修正しました。

sen.j: 馬上資格のない中小姓の上位に位置する馬上武士の階級と位置づけられていた。
sen.e: They were ranked to Bajobushi (a samurai on horseback) which was part of the upper Nakakosho (groom or stableman) without the Bajoshikaku.
They were ranked as Bajobushi (a samurai on horseback) which was part of the upper Nakakosho (groom or stableman) without the Bajoshikaku.
They were regarded as a class of mounted retainers higher in rank than grooms or stablemen called "nakakosho," who were not allowed to ride horses.
sen.cmt: FBに基づき修正しました。

sen.j: 赤穂浪士四十七士のうち馬廻だった者は堀部武庸ら15名で、全員が200石から100石取りである。
sen.e: Among forty seven Ako Roshi warriors (lordless samurai of Ako domain), there were fifteen Umamawari people including Taketsune HORIBE, who were entitled to a hundred to two hundred-koku (of rice) (a unit of volume: rice 1-koku is 180.39 liter.)

Among forty seven Ako Roshi warriors (lordless samurai of the Ako domain), there were fifteen Umamawari individuals, including Taketsune HORIBE, who were entitled to a hundred to two hundred-koku (of rice) (a unit of volume: rice 1-koku is 180.39 liter.)
Of the forty-seven Ako samurai, fifteen were umamawari, including Takesune HORIBE, and these fifteen members were all earning incomes of 100 to 200 koku.
sen.cmt: FBに基づき修正しました。

sen.j: 重臣とまでは言えないものの、上士と呼べる家禄の者たちである。
sen.e: They were people with Karoku (hereditary stipend) appropriate to be considered Joshi (superior warrior.)
They were people with a Karoku (hereditary stipend) considered appropriate for Joshi (superior warrior.)
Although they were not necessarily chief retainers, they all had incomes for upper-class retainers.
sen.cmt: FBに基づき修正しました。

sen.j: これが馬上資格のない中小姓だと最上の大高忠雄でも30石取りであるからこの階級差は歴然である。
sen.e: Referring to Nakakosho without the Bajoshikaku, however, even if Tadao OTAKA was the most affluent one, he was entitled only to thirty-koku, and the rank difference was evident.
Referring to Nakakosho without the Bajoshikaku, however, even if Tadao OTAKA was the most affluent, he was entitled to only thirty-koku, and the difference in rank was evident.

There was a profound difference between these retainers and middle-ranking retainers who were not allowed to ride horses - Tadao OTAKA, a middle-ranking retainer with the largest income, only had an income of 30 koku.
sen.cmt: FBに基づき修正しました。
